tossups.question: In the mythology of the Ainu people, a goddess of this domain works with Mintakoro Kamuy. That goddess is Kamuy-huci. When engaged in harmful behaviour, deities of this domain can become barabashka, and they may flee if they are mentioned to others or paid for their services, though they will accept gifts of clothes. Roman deities of this place were worshipped at lararia and included the (*) Penates. In Cologne, deities of this type are said to hate peas, but offerings of food like milk or butter are said appease these deities. To the Greeks, the rules of xenia applied to people who entered these locations and indicated that a gift should be given to the owner of one of these places. Domovoi and brownies are primarily associated with--for 10 points--what domain which, along with the hearth, was the realm of Hestia?
tossups.answer: homes [accept households, accept hearth before “barabashka” and anti-prompt before mention] <Ed. HB>

tossups.question: This justice and William Brennan both supported the idea that the death penalty does not deter crime in their dissents in the case of Gregg v. Georgia. This justice held that an employee suing a labor union for breach of fair representation is entitled to a jury trial in his majority opinion for Teamsters v. Terry. In an early case, this man and fellow lawyer Samuel Friedman defended Joseph Spell, a chauffeur accused of raping socialite Eleanor Strubing. In a press conference announcing his 1991 retirement from the (*) Supreme Court, this man denied rumors that he was upset with the Court’s conservative direction. This man argued cases such as Sweatt v. Painter and Shelley v. Kraemer while serving as executive director of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. For 10 points, name this man who argued for the plaintiffs in Brown v. Board of Education, the Supreme Court’s first African-American justice.

Possibly in response to a piece of text from one of these objects, an athlete wore a shirt that said “Adopt a Cat” on it after his team’s win against Melbourne United. The originator of these objects supposedly couldn’t eat or sleep after a reveal about them was made public. According to a subreddit, an Instagram account owned by the owner of these objects is named quiresaltan, who said “your little ass ain’t playing varsity, u better start rapping lmaooo” to Instagram user @gohamyoungbull. One text from one of these objects was directed towards (*) Cole Caswell, criticized Billy Donovan and said the team’s roster was “just him and Russ.” For 10 points, identify these alternate social media accounts made by a former Oklahoma City forward who left to join the Golden State Warriors.
tossups.answer: Kevin Durant’s Twitter Account[s] [accept obvious equivalents like “Tweets sent by Durant from alternate accounts;” prompt on Durant’s social media and on a partial answer] <HB>

tossups.question: An algorithm for completing this task on distributed memory systems was created by Lynn Cannon, though in modern usage it has been supplanted by the SUMM algorithm. Cohn et al. suggested in 2005 that this problem could be solved in quadratic time, although there is currently no proof of that result. The to-date lowest time complexity for this task was achieved by Le Gall with a modification of the (*) Coppersmith-Winograd method, which beats an algorithm which performs this task in approximately “O of n to the log of 7” time instead of the naive “O of n to the 3.” That algorithm splits the input into four pieces and makes use of seven separate equations, and is named for its discoverer, Volker Strassen. For 10 points, name this binary operation that takes two rectangular arrays of integers and returns their product.

One leader of this country intentionally leaked information about the American Secretary of State’s upcoming visit to his socialist doctor, with the resulting leftist protests allowing him to avoid agreeing to the U.S.’s plans. Another prime minister of this country won the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize, along with Sean MacBride, for his work on nuclear non-proliferation. That man’s brother, another prime minister of this country, was known as “America’s Favorite (*) War Criminal,” since he was a suspect in Class A war crimes but was never charged. That man was the grandfather of this country’s current prime minister, who has a namesake economic policy based on quantitative easing and controversially visited Yasukuni Shrine. For 10 points, name this country currently led by Shinzo Abe.
tossups.answer: Japan [or Nippon-koku; or Nihon-koku] [others mentioned in the question are Yoshida Shigeru Sato Eisaku and Kishi Nobusuke] <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: In two paired poems by this author, the first speaker asks "how to keep" beauty from "vanishing away," to which the second responds "give beauty back" to "beauty's self and beauty's giver." This author of "The Leaden Echo and the Golden Echo" wrote another poem that describes the soul crying "what I do is me: for that I came." This man's poems were published posthumously by a friend who served as UK Poet Laureate during World War 1. This author of "As kingfishers catch fire, dragonflies draw flame" repeated “Rural scene, a rural scene / Sweet especial rural scene” at the end of his poem (*) “Binsey Poplars.” This poet praised "the achieve of, the mastery of the thing!" in a poem addressed to "morning's minion," a "dapple-dawn-drawn Falcon." For 10 points, name this Catholic poet who pioneered "sprung rhythm" in poems like "The Windhover" and "Pied Beauty."

Jonathan Allen attributed a so-called “anti-procrusteanism” view to this thinker, who agreed with Rickert that human and natural sciences sought different types of knowledge. This thinker discussed the choice between healing a wound on one's leg and cutting the leg off in "The Retreat to the Inner Citadel," a section of an essay that also examines the transformation of Kantian individualism into totalitarianism. This proponent of value (*) pluralism wrote an essay that suggested a dichotomy between the presence of self-mastery and the absence of external constraints, concepts he labeled "positive" and "negative." He analyzed Tolstoy’s theory of history in an essay in which the two title animals are categories of people who do or don’t view the world through a single idea. For 10 points, name this author of "Two Concepts of Liberty" and "The Hedgehog and the Fox."

This man promised his daughter’s hand to the man who could capture the city of Debir, which was accomplished by his nephew Othniel. This man drove out the three sons of Anak after he was granted the city of Hebron, and according to a Midrashic legend he had earlier gone to Hebron alone to visit the graves of the Patriarchs. This man’s father Jephunneh was a (*) Kenizzite, suggesting that this man was not originally an Israelite. This man, who is not the namesake of a biblical book, threatened his companions with a sword after they refused to bring back fruit from a certain land which was flowing with milk and honey. For 10 points, which member of the tribe of Judah was, along with Joshua, one of two spies to recommend to Moses that the Israelites conquer Canaan?

Allen Jones created a 1970 sculpture with this title depicting a woman lying on her back with her legs in the air. During the Profumo affair, Christine Keeler appeared in a photograph that helped popularize one of these things. That one of these things was designed by Arne Jacobsen, who also created one of these called the Egg. One of these called the Wassily was created by Marcel (*) Breuer. The “warm, receptive” look of a baseball mitt inspired a 1956 one of these by Charles and Ray Eames, who also pioneered the use of shock mounts on the bottoms of these things. One of these called the Womb and one called the Tulip were designed by Eero Saarinen. For 10 points, name these articles of furniture, whose swivel variety was invented by Thomas Jefferson.

By choosing the Coulomb gauge, this equation can be derived by using a Green’s function for the resulting vector Poisson equation. Under the assumption of steady-state, Jefimenko’s second equation reduces to this equation. A fluid dynamics analogue of this equation uses vorticity in place of the (*) current and can be used to find the velocity induced at a point by a vortex filament. For conductors with volume, this equation is represented as the triple integral of an inverse cube relation, and it can be understood as the analogue of Coulomb’s law for steady state currents. For 10 points, name this linear analogue of Ampere’s law, which describes the magnetic field generated by a steady electric current, usually through a wire.

A novel by this author was praised by the critic George Wyndham for having us view an event through the protagonist’s “morbidly sensitive” temperament. A character in a novella by this author only respects fire engines after he becomes a truck driver. A novella by this author ends with the title character’s mother screaming “I’ll forgive her!” at her funeral. That novella by this author centers on a character who resorts to (*) prostitution after her boyfriend, the bartender Pete, is seduced by Nellie. The protagonist of a novel by this author hopes to receive the title wound to make up for his fleeing from the Battle of Chancellorsville. This author’s protagonists include Henry Fleming. For 10 points, name this American author of Maggie: A Girl of the Streets and The Red Badge of Courage.

Cats and nonsense pictures were used in a study by James Haxby about a “distributed coding” model of this process. Research by Woody Bledsoe and others pioneered computer analysis related to this process. Morris Moscovitch described a “patient CK” who, after suffering a car accident, had normal abilities at this faculty but severe impairment of a related faculty. Justine Sergent discovered that this faculty takes place within a namesake area located within the (*) fusiform gyrus. This faculty can make errors in detecting anomalies when presented with upside-down stimuli during the Thatcher effect. This cognitive ability is impaired in individuals who suffer from prosopagnosia. For 10 points, name this cognitive faculty, which involves perceiving and processing features like lips, eyes, and noses.
tossups.answer: face recognition [or face perception or face processing or any equivalent answer that uses the word “face”, prompt on “vision” or “cognitively processing visual objects” or similar] <Ed. HB>

tossups.question: This family’s tomb was rediscovered in a vineyard in 1614, and its only intact sarcophagus has an epigraph which is a rare example of Saturnian verse. A member of this family named Metellus was a prominent optimate and commanded the center of Pompey’s army at the battle of Pharsalus. After a member of this family named Lucius was accused of corruption, his brother publicly destroyed their military campaign’s financial records in protest against the senate, and later died in exile in (*) Liternum. In that brother’s most notable military victory, he placed his formations perpendicular to the enemy’s, allowing his enemy’s war elephants to pass by harmlessly. For 10 points, name this family, which included a Roman general who defeated Hannibal at the battle of Zama and earned the nickname “Africanus.”
tossups.answer: Scipio [accept Scipio Barbatus; or Metellus Scipio; or Lucius Cornelius Scipio Asiaticus; or Publius Cornelius Scipio Africanus] <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: A work in this genre is given its nickname from a pattern first seen in the opening half notes: A down to D, up to E, down to A. A work in this genre concludes with a movement titled "The Difficult Decision," in which the slow introduction is marked with the question "Must it be?," and the main theme is marked "It must be." One of these works ends with a B-flat major allegro movement that replaced a much larger section, which Stravinsky called (*) a “contemporary piece of music that will be contemporary forever." Mozart wrote a piece in this genre to mock the techniques of his contemporaries nicknamed “Dissonance.” Six of Mozart’s works in this genre were dedicated to Haydn, who himself wrote a set dedicated to Count Erdody that includes the “Emperor.” For 10 points, name these chamber works scored for two violins, a viola, and a cello.
tossups.answer: string quartets [prompt on a partial answer] <Ed. JS>

tossups.question: One ruler of this name blocked off a sewer tunnel leading from his room to prevent tennis balls from getting lost, which later prevented him from escaping his assassination. That man’s son who shared this name invited one of his most powerful lords to dinner, and personally stabbed him to death for refusing to break an alliance with the Lord of the Isles. The newlywed queen of a ruler of this name (*) was shocked to find that his palace already had a nursery for his many illegitimate children. That ruler with this name greatly expanded his country’s navy and built the carrack Great Michael, but was killed at the battle of Flodden Field fighting against forces led by Catherine of Aragon. For 10 points, give this name held by several Scottish kings, the sixth of whom succeeded Elizabeth I to the English crown.

This play’s author stated that he was inspired to write it by seeing a bust of Winston Churchill and experiencing a sudden desire to knock it over. One character in this play makes her husband apologize to their servant Joseph after he denigrates Joseph’s religious beliefs. A character in this play, who disowned his medical student son as an “eater of leftovers,” displays a blood and semen-stained cloth in a marketplace as proof of consummating a new marriage. That character describes himself as “the master of his fate” while relating the tale of the (*) Not-I bird to the Praise Singer. In this play, Olunde takes the place of the title character, who is prevented from carrying out his religious duty by the intervention of colonial administrator Pilkings. For 10 points, identify this 1975 play about Elesin Oba’s attempt to commit ritual suicide, a work by Wole Soyinka.
tossups.answer: Death and the King’s Horseman <Ed. DS>

tossups.question: This element is bonded to several hydroxyquinolinato ligands in a compound commonly used to make organic LEDs. The K-alpha emissions of magnesium and this element are used as X-ray sources in XPS. Nitriles can be converted to aldehydes using a reducing agent containing two atoms of this element coordinated to isobutyl groups and hydrogen atoms. The chloride of this non-iron element is typically used as a (*) Lewis acid catalyst to facilitate the acylation of a benzene ring via electrophilic aromatic substitution in the Friedel-Crafts reaction. This element is extracted from its primary ore in the form of its amphoteric hydroxide and amphoteric oxide in the Bayer process, before being extracted in its pure form in the Hall-Héroult process. Bauxite is the major ore of, for 10 points, what metal commonly used for beverage cans?

One of this author’s characters states that the word of God may have been “pronounced in caprice, as a whim,” but that “it is still the principle of our world” when explaining why he never breaks his word. In another story by this author, a character gives a speech stating “that which we have rejected is poured upon us abundantly;” that character is General Loewenhielm. In a story by this author, a peasant dies saving her son Goske from prison by (*) mowing a field in one day. This author wrote about a turtle being delivered to Berlevaag after that story’s title character wins ten thousand francs in the lottery. This author of “Sorrow-Acre” wrote a story in which a cook spends all her money hosting a single dinner, “Babette’s Feast.” For 10 points, name this Danish author, who also wrote a memoir about life on a Kenyan coffee plantation in Out of Africa.

Description acceptable Prior to the start of one of these conflicts, a missionary was saved from human sacrifice after getting lucky in a horse ritual. It didn’t take place in Russia, but a knight involved in these conflicts composed a rhyming chronicle of them. During the battle of Lyndanisse in one of these conflicts, a Danish army supposedly turned the tide after receiving what is now the flag of Denmark. The military order known as the (*) Sword-Brothers was founded during one of these conflicts, but they were defeated by Semigallians at the battle of Saule, and later merged with the Teutonic Knights. During these conflicts, the regions of Prussia and Livonia were Christianized. For 10 points, name these conflicts in which knightly orders invaded Pagan lands along the coast of a Northern European sea.
tossups.answer: Baltic Crusades [accept Northern Crusades; accept Livonian Crusade until “Livonia” is read; prompt on crusades] <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: The chemotherapy drug mitomycin C is used to prevent scarring in surgeries to treat this non-cancer disease. This disease commonly occurs in individuals who have another disease caused by an excess buildup of fibrillar proteins, called pseudoexfoliation syndrome. Drugs for the treatment of this disease include carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like brinzolamide and prostaglandin analogs like latanoprost. This disease can be diagnosed by observing a large (*) cup-to-disc ratio. Improper drainage through the anterior chamber, Schlemm's canal, or the trabecular meshwork causes this disease, which is classified as closed-angle or open-angle based on the status of the iridocorneal angle. For 10 points, name this condition in which a buildup of aqueous humor leads to excessive intraocular pressure, which causes optic nerve damage and progressive vision loss.

(TB) This composer wrote an overture based on the tune of King Christian stood by the lofty mast. This composer began one of his symphonies with the bassoons and french horns playing the note A-flat in a long, triplet short, triplet long pattern. A bassoon solo in a symphony by this composer starts by repeating this rhythm three times: two eighth notes, quarter note, half note. This composer wrote a programmatic work for a benefit concert to help those wounded in the (*) Serbian–Ottoman War. This composer used a Byron poem as the basis for an unnumbered symphony, and included a “limping waltz” in another. This composer incorporated intertwining melodies of La Marseillaise and God Save the Tsar at the end of one of his works. For 10 points, name this Russian composer of the Pathetique Symphony and the 1812 overture.

bonuses.leadin: This place expels poets as they can only create imitations, and it is ruled by philosopher kings. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Magnesia [accept answers about the city of the Magnetes]
parts: Name this utopia described in a Platonic dialogue. Glaucon dismissed an earlier version one as being inhabited by pigs.

A later Platonic attempt at describing a utopia is this recipient of the title statues in the Laws. It’s often considered to be the more realistic and measured response to the naive ideal of The Republic.

In The Republic’s myth of the metals, the people of this metal, along with iron, are told to be the builders and the producers of The Republic. Their children, however, are not necessarily producers and can rise to auxiliary level.

bonuses.leadin: This poem declares, "The 'Internationale,' let it thunder / when the last antisemite on earth / is buried for ever." For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Joseph Stalin [or Joseph Vissarionovich Stalin; or Ioseb Dzhugashvili]
parts: Name this poem by Yevgeny Yevtushenko, which notes that "no monument stands over" the title location where a 1941 massacre took place. This poem inspired Shostakovich’s 13th symphony.

Yevtushenko wrote a 1961 poem titled for the "heirs of" this deceased Soviet leader. He was described as a "Kremlin mountaineer" with "huge laughing cockroaches on his top lip" in a namesake "epigram" by Osip Mandelstam.

Yevtushenko was kicked out of a literary institute named for this other writer after the publication of his overly individualistic poem “Zima Junction.” Stalin personally served as one of this author’s pallbearers.

bonuses.leadin: This quantity equals the covariance between two variables, divided by the product of the standard deviations in each of the two variables. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity from statistics, represented by a coefficient which ranges from -1 to 1, called Pearson's R, which measures how two variables are related.

This scientist names a rank measure of correlation, denoted rho, which quantitatively assesses whether or not the variables increase or decrease together; for example, the graphs of y equals x cubed and y equals e to the x are perfectly correlated under his measure.

While Pearson's r is a measure of linearity, Spearman's rho is a measure of this property. A function with this property will be strictly non-increasing or strictly non-decreasing as the input increases, for any value of the input.

bonuses.leadin: Loyalist customs officer John Malcolm was subjected to this punishment twice, although luckily for him he was fully clothed the first time. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: tarring and feathering [or being tarred and feathered]
parts: Name this form of public humiliation, sometimes applied by mobs in colonial America. Joseph Smith suffered this punishment at the hands of an Ohio mob in 1832.
Malcolm resided in this city, where the Sons of Liberty had a notable Tea Party.
Previously, Malcolm had travelled to North Carolina to help the British during the Regulator War, during which citizens led by Herman Husband rebelled against this Royal Governor.

bonuses.leadin: This action is typically performed by Babaaláwos or Iyalawos, and it follows from the teachings of Orunmila. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: divination [accept equivalents, such as divining or prophecy; accept Ifá]
parts: Name this action that is usually done with the aid of such objects as the Opele or Ikin.
Ikin are objects of this type, which are used to divine by throwing them against the cowrie shell decorated Opon Ifá, and determining which of the 256 signs their pattern displays.

Ifá is a common practice amongst these West African peoples, who also use ritual drum beats to allow specific Orishas to “mount,” or possess, them. This group of the Osun Osogbo festival also has large Christian and Muslim memberships.

bonuses.leadin: Mark Strand wrote a pair of villanelles inspired by this man's paintings The Philosopher's Conquest and The Disquieting Muses. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this metaphysical painter who showed a girl rolling a hoop in his Mystery and Melancholy of a Street.
De Chirico's painting The Nostalgia of the Infinite inspired the box art for this Fumito Ueda-designed Playstation 2 game, whose protagonist protects a princess named Yorda from shadow-creatures.

The cover for this band's 1984 single "Thieves Like Us" was based on the de Chirico painting The Evil Genius of a King. This band was formed by the remaining members of Joy Division after Ian Curtis committed suicide.

bonuses.leadin: One model of this process that was popular in the 1950s came from the so-called Michigan School. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process. Arrow’s impossibility theorem says that no system of this process can exist that satisfies the three fairness criteria, one of which says that there is no dictator.
This other criterion for Arrow's impossibility theorem states that if a voting system prefers A to B, adding in additional candidates does not change the ranking of A relative to B.

Following the median voter theorem, this model of voting suggests that since voters would choose a candidate that is most similar to their linearly modeled political ideology, candidates would then try to appeal the median voter’s ideology.

bonuses.leadin: This man founded the Bechuanaland Democratic Party and began his country’s history of political stability and economic growth. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this member of the Bamangwato tribe, who became his country’s first president after returning from an exile caused by his marriage to a British woman named Ruth Williams.
Khama was the president of this southern African country, which is mostly covered by the Kalahari Desert and is currently led by Khama’s son Ian.
The world’s largest mine for this mineral is located in Botswana’s town of Orapa, and much of Botswana’s economy is based on mining it.

bonuses.leadin: This theory was initially presented in 1972 as an alternative to phyletic gradualism. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this theory, which supposes that speciation occurs rapidly between very long periods of stasis, naturally explaining why there are so many gaps in the fossil record.
The idea that evolution occurs via punctuated equilibrium was developed by Niles Eldredge and this paleontologist and biologist, who wrote pop science books on evolution such as The Panda's Thumb.

Gould coined this term to describe a process where a feature evolves for one purpose, but is later used for another. One example is feathers, which seem to have evolved for thermoregulation but were co-opted by later organisms to be used as an airfoil.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about things you can learn about urban geography by playing the game Mini Metro. For 10 points each:
parts: Lots of costly bridges are required to reach this area of Hong Kong. This region is often defined as the part of Hong Kong contiguous with the Chinese mainland.
Stations in Mini Metro in Osaka can be serviced considerably faster, since the player has the option to use these very fast Japanese trains often used for inter-city transit.

This city is located entirely on an island, which makes connecting it to outlying districts like Longueuil kind of annoying. The progressive Valerie Plante recently won a mayoral election in this city

bonuses.leadin: The IEC standard diagrams for depicting these systems use rectangles instead of the familiar jagged lines for a common component. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these connected systems, which may include devices such as batteries and inductors.

This French telegrapher’s namesake theorem states that a circuit consisting of only resistances and current sources can be replaced by an equivalent circuit with an equivalent voltage source in series with an equivalent resistance. That theorem is dual to Norton’s theorem.

Thévenin’s theorem only applies to resistive DC circuits described by this adjective, meaning that output is proportional to the input. Components described by this adjective include capacitors and resistors, but not diodes and transistors.

bonuses.leadin: A brother in this play is happy to make an honest living allowing carnival goers to shoot him in the back of the head, which allows them to reenact the assassination of Abraham Lincoln. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Their Eyes Were Watching God <Ed. JO>
parts: Name this 2001 play, which concerns the trials and tribulations of the brothers Booth and Lincoln.
Topdog/Underdog won the 2002 Pulitzer Prize for Drama for this Kentucky playwright, whose other plays include In the Blood and Fucking A.
Parks also wrote the screenplay for the 2005 film adaptation of this Zora Neale Hurston novel, which starred Halle Berry as Janie and the underappreciated Michael Ealy as Tea Cake.

bonuses.leadin: The USSR started Operation X to ship weapons to one side in this conflict. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Spanish Civil War [or Guerra Civil Espanola]
parts: Name this conflict, during which international units, including the Abraham Lincoln Brigade and Garibaldi Brigade, fought on the Republican side.
This Generalissimo was dictator of Spain until his 1975 death.

The Spanish Civil War broke out during the term of this leftist President, who ordered Spain’s gold reserve to be sent to the Soviet Union before his government was driven out of Madrid and then Barcelona.

bonuses.leadin: An adherent of this style named Baude Cordier composed several pieces of "eye music,” including a circular canon written in a circle and the heart-shaped love song "Belle, Bonne, Sage.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: harp [accept pedal harp; or concert harp]
parts: Identify this style of medieval music, examples of which were collected in the Chantilly and Modena codices. It succeeded the ars nova.
A piece of ars subtilior eye music by Jacob Senleches is notated on an illustration of one of these instruments. The standard modern concert version has 47 strings and seven pedals.
This famed poet and foremost composer of the ars nova style wrote the Messe de Nostre Dame, which is the first complete setting of the Ordinary of the Mass attributed to a single person.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about a work by 17th-century scientist and writer Margaret Cavendish.
parts: Cavendish published this early work of science fiction, alongside her reply to Robert Hooke’s Micrographia. It tells the story of an expedition to the North Pole that ends up in a utopian world of anthropomorphic animals.

The protagonists escape into Cavendish’s Blazing World at the conclusion of this other writer’s Black Dossier, the best entry in his League of Extraordinary Gentlemen series. This author also wrote V for Vendetta.

Siri Hustvedt borrowed the title of The Blazing World for her Booker-nominated novel about a woman in this profession, who uses male names to get more attention for her work. Elaine Risley in Cat’s Eye and Lily Briscoe in To the Lighthouse have this profession.

bonuses.leadin: DAPI [da-pee] is a fluorescent molecule typically used to perform this process. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: staining [prompt on answers indicating that you are using a chemical to improve the contrast in some form of microscopy]
gel electrophoresis [prompt on electrophoresis accept types, such as polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis which is abbreviated PAGE]
parts: Name this process, which is often performed using a mixture of hematoxylin and eosin. When prepping for a certain analytical technique, it is often performed alongside fixation.

When trying to image samples that aren't or cannot be stained, you can enhance the contrast using this form of microscopy, which uses an optical setup which excludes the unscattered beam from the final image.
Ethidium bromide is a common stain used in this technique, which involves embedding a macromolecule, like DNA or proteins, in agarose and applying a voltage to separate them based on size or charge.

bonuses.leadin: The illustrated Cheng-Gao editions of this novel added an additional 40 chapters with dubious authorial provenance which are not found in the earlier Rouge editions. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Dream of the Red Chamber [or The Story of the Stone; or Hong lou meng; accept Red Chamber Dream or A Dream of Red Mansions]
confession [the latter is De Quincey’s Confessions of an English Opium Eater]
parts: Name this Qing dynasty-era novel by Cao Xueqin (tsao shway-cheen), in which Jia Baoyu is born with a piece of jade in his mouth.

The influential survey A Brief History of Chinese Fiction attributes Dream of the Red Chamber’s success to it being both an autobiography and an example of this genre. An English work titled for this genre pioneered “impassioned prose” and begins “I here present you, courteous reader, with the record of a remarkable period in my life.”
A Brief History of Chinese Fiction was written by this 20th century author, who compared Chinese society to "an iron house without windows" in the preface to his collection Call to Arms.

bonuses.leadin: This piece maintains a consistent two chord piano vamp, even through a Joe Morello drum solo. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: 2+2+2+3 [“two plus two plus two plus three” or “two two two three”, accept a clear description, but the numbers must be in the correct order]
parts: Name this E-minor jazz standard originally recorded by the Dave Brubeck Quartet, whose name comes from its unconventional time signature.

Another unusual time signature from Time Out is the 9/8 [nine-eight] "Blue Rondo à la Turk", whose stumbling aksak-inspired rhythm is presented in sets of three measures in this non-standard grouping, followed by one measure in the more traditional 3+3+3 [three three three].
The final two tracks on the B-side of Time Out are in the even rarer time signature of 6/4. Name either one.

bonuses.leadin: Many of this artist’s paintings include his heraldic symbol of a bat-winged serpent. For 10 points each,
answers_sanitized: Lucas Cranach the Elder [prompt on Cranach]
parts: Identify this sixteenth-century court painter to the electors of Saxony. He made several paintings of Judith with the head of Holofernes, in which Judith wears a big red hat with feathers.

Cranach’s best known portrait is of this man, who was one of his personal friends. Some art historians have connected Cranach’s interest in the Judith story with this theologian’s ideological struggle against Charles V.

Despite his Lutheran allegiance, Cranach accepted a commission to paint Cardinal Albert von Brandenburg as this figure. His composition was heavily derived from Durer’s woodcut of this saint writing in his study, which features a tame lion in the foreground.

bonuses.leadin: No one is quite sure where these people came from, though they may have been displaced by the eruption of Santorini. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this group, which invaded Egypt during the reign of Ramses III. Their appearance in the Middle East may have precipitated the Bronze Age Collapse.
This empire based in Anatolia collapsed around the same time the Sea Peoples appeared, suggesting that the two events were linked. This empire fought Egypt at the battle of Kadesh.
The Sea Peoples’ exploits are recorded at this temple built by Ramesses III to celebrate his victory over them. It is our only source for a list of the Sea Peoples’ names.
